turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You fucked me, man? Why would you do that?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: What do you mean 'why'?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Answer the question, shitball.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Look, you asked me to follow your girl around, and I did and I started to like her, and then I realized I just couldn't in good conscience do it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Do what?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Turn her over to a stalker.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What?! You're calling me a stalker?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: That's right -- if you weren't you would've looked for her yourself!

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Oh Christ... poor dog.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You're a sick man, you know that?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Yeah well fuck you! You just can't stand the fact that it was my turn.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Your turn?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: That's right, hot shot! My turn. What's the matter with me, huh? Why can't I ever get the great girl? Give the big pig with the B.O. to Healy, right? Well I was sick of it, man! No more -- it was my turn. It was time for me... time for me... to be happy.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well you didn't have to blow us both out of the water. Jesus Christ, just because she found out about you, why'd you have to take me down with you?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm talking about the letter, asshole.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Are you telling me you didn't send Mary a letter outlining our deal?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Why the fuck would I do that? I'd be screwing myself.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Pleasure to meet you, Patrick.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Same here.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Mainly I work out of Boston.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Boston, huh? Did you get your degree up there?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Yes yes, I did get my degree up there.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Harvard?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: You bet.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Did you study under Kim Greene?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Among others.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Kim and I are close friends!

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Well, I'll tell her I ran into you.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: You mean him.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Really? But he's been married for twenty years -- they've got six kids.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Nice smokescreen, isn't it?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Have you been to  Let's see -- Santiago, Chile?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Absolutely! I was there twice last year. Which building is yours?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Do you know the... soccer stadium?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Did you build the Estadio Olympico?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: No... just down the street, the Amigo Tower.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: I'm sorry, I'm not familiar with it. What style?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Uh, sort of nouveau Deco... with a big vestibule. Check it out next time you're up there.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: You know, I really should take your card.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Oh look, it's Doob! Will you excuse me a minute, Tucker?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Okay, Pat, take it easy -- don't do anything stupid.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Who the fuck do you think you are making up that bullshit about me?!

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Whoa, whoa -- I don't know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Maybe this'll jog your memory.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: That stalker Ted got to you, right? You're working for him, aren't you, you little shit?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: You what?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: You heard me, goddamnit. I... I love her.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: I'm a phony -- just like you, man.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: I mean I'm a fucking fraud. I'm no architect. Don't be a putz -- who's been to Santiago twice in a year?  Estadio Olimpico -- please!

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: But... but you knew people at Harvard.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: I knew shit. The only thing I knew was that you were a fake and I made up everything else.  My real name's Norm. I deliver pizzas.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Bullshit!

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: ...So then in '94 I went back to Dade Community College for a semester and when the Wal-Mart cashier job fell through I hooked up with the Pizza Barn.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: And you met Mary how?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Just dumb luck. I delivered a pie to her one night and she answered the door in her nightgown -- that was it for me. I went home that night, shaved my beard, and a week later I was laid out in her office with a broken back.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: How'd you manage that one?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Friend. Baseball bat.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Nice.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Oh yeah, the plan was going along just fine until you showed up.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Hey, hey, hey, I'm not the one who started telling bald-faced lies about the competition -- that's crossing the line!

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: What line? The day you first laid your oily rap on my future wife you started a war!

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Future wife? Get real, man -- you're nothing more than a glorified brother in her eyes.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Why you son of a --

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: That stalkin' son-of-a-bitch!

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Fucking sickening.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: How many is that?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Four.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: That seems like a lot of speed for a little pooch -- you sure it won't kill him?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: I never said that.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Ho-ly shit.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Hey, this is a pretty nice place.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Sully...! What the fuck happened here?!

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: You little fuck.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: You fucking prick, we had a deal -- you said you wouldn't fuck me and I wouldn't fuck you until we had this fuck out of the fucking picture.  You crossed the line, man.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: I swear! I didn't tell her nothing! You probably did it yourself, you piece of shit.

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Oh that makes a lot of sense. Why would I rat myself out?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Like I'm going to try to figure out a guy who's idea of courting is blowing farts in the chick's face

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: You were following us?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Don't flatter yourself -- I was following her, I always do. How the hell you think I got rid of Mary's boyfriend Steve?

turns.speaker: HEALY
turns.text: Oh... Sully.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Look, if it wasn't you who sent the letter, and it wasn't me who sent it?

turns.speaker: HITCHHIKER
turns.text: Thanks for picking me up.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No prob, I could use the company. I've been on the road going on fifteen hours straight.

turns.speaker: HITCHHIKER
turns.text: I know how you feel -- I been standing in the same spot for the last five hours. You know it's against the law to pick up a hitchhiker in this state.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That must make it tough.

turns.speaker: HITCHHIKER
turns.text: Sucks. So what's up? You some kind of salesman or something?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Nah. I'm... I'm nothing.

turns.speaker: HITCHHIKER
turns.text: Oh. Well I am.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Hm?

turns.speaker: HITCHHIKER
turns.text: A salesman -- that's what I am. I mean, I'm gonna be anyway. I'm starting my own company -- video sales -- just as soon as I get enough seed money.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: 'That right? Good for you.

turns.speaker: HITCHHIKER
turns.text: Yeah, you wouldn't believe my idea -- it's a home run. You ever hear of Eight-Minute Abs?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: The exercise tape? Sure, I've seen it on T.V.

turns.speaker: HITCHHIKER
turns.text: Two million copies it sold last year. Two million, man. But not next year -- my idea's gonna blow them outta the water. Get this:  Seven-Minute Abs.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I see where you're going.

turns.speaker: HITCHHIKER
turns.text: Think about it. You walk into a video store and you see Eight-Minute Abs and right next to it you see Seven- Minute Abs -- which one you gonna spring for?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'd go with the seven.

turns.speaker: HITCHHIKER
turns.text: Bingo. Especially since we guarantee you'll get every bit as good a work- out.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: How do you guarantee that?

turns.speaker: HITCHHIKER
turns.text: Well it's the company motto: 'If you ain't happy we'll send you the extra minute.'

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Huh. That sounds great.  Unless someone else comes out with Six-Minute Abs.

turns.speaker: JOANIE
turns.text: No, it should be 'a hockey player with great pecs.'

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Ugh, not pecs. Sounds like one of those guys with a fish-net shirt and a banana hammock.

turns.speaker: JOANIE
turns.text: I can live with those reflections.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm sick of these calorie-countin' pansies. Give me a guy who likes kielbasa and beer and playing thirty- six holes and still has enough energy to take me and Warren out to a ballgame.

turns.speaker: JOANIE
turns.text: Jeez, I don't know where you're ever going to find a guy like that.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But here's the rub. The guy I'm talking about has got to be self- employed.

turns.speaker: JOANIE
turns.text: Yeah, and you'd probably dump the poor guy halfway to Katmandu.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What's that supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: JOANIE
turns.text: It means you're too hard on guys.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No I'm not.

turns.speaker: JOANIE
turns.text: Oh come off it, Mare. What about what's-his-name... Steverino? You could've at least passed the baton on that one.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yeah, Steve. Steve was all right for awhile.

turns.speaker: JOANIE
turns.text: All right for awhile? The guy's good- looking, rich, witty. He was a god.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I don't know, it was complicated. He's in San Francisco, I'm in Miami.  Besides, Magda's psychic dog hated him.

turns.speaker: JOANIE
turns.text: Is that old crab still with you? Mary, you said you were putting her up for a month -- it's been a year and a half.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Ah, she's okay.

turns.speaker: JOANIE
turns.text: What? Steve seemed to put up with Warren.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I don't want someone who'll put up with him. I want someone who will enjoy him, the way I do. Do you know what he told my friend Tucker? He said he would've popped the question a lot earlier if Warren wasn't in my life.  Well he is in my life and I'm goddamn lucky to have him. The hell with Steve.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Have you been up all night again?

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Bet your ass I have. It's an important job, Neighborhood Watch is.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Neighborhood Watch? Is that what you call listening in on stranger's phone conversations?

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: These ain't strangers, they're neighbors. This only picks up signals in a half-mile radius.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Meaning?

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Meaning these are the people you live amongst, you got a right to know if they're creeps. For instance, did you know there's a guy down the hall cheating on his wife?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You picked that up on the scanner. We gotta move.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: I confirmed it on the scanner. I knew something was up because Puffy used to bark like hell whenever he saw him and you know Puffy only barks at bad people.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Magda, Puffy barks at everybody.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: That's because there's a lot of bad people out there. Hey, Puffy tried to warn you about that Steve guy you was seeing -- he was a fucking asswipe -- but you had to find out for yourself, didn't you?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Okay, you win. Now try to get some sleep, huh.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Jesus, Mary, you gotta hear this -- some cop's staking out this broad's apartment.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No time, Magda, my show's starting.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: So who's the lucky guy?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Name's Patrick, I met him at the driving range.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Good lookin'?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He's no Steve Young.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: What's he like?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I don't know. He's kind of a mook.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: What's a mook?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You know, a mookalone, a schlep.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Then why you going out with him if he's a schlep?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Come on, Magda  It's like that movie Harold and Maude.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: I don't watch the new ones.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: This one's almost thirty years old. It's about a young kid and an old lady who fall in love.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: That's exactly why I don't watch 'em anymore -- it's bullshit! Why the hell would an old lady go for a young kid?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: The point is, love isn't about money or social standing or age, it's about connecting with someone, having things in common kindred spirits.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Fuck kindred spirits. My little Puffy here's gonna tell you all you need to know about this guy in about two seconds flat. If he starts yapping, he's a loser; if Puffy's relaxed... well, you got yourself a keeper.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sure.  Uh, Magda, why don't you get some more cheese and crackers...?

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Oh, yeah, of course, dear.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Bundt cake?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Must have a sweet tooth. See if you can find some cookies.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Hey hey, what did you say Pat's last name was?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Healy.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: I'm buying bananas tonight.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Back when I was your age I always used to make myself a big banana split after sex. I think you're gonna need one tonight.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Don't get ahead of yourself. You'll probably need it before I will.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Don't bet on it. Last time I had a pap smear the guy needed leather gloves and an oyster shucker.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: So maybe I could find a nice gentleman to take you to the movies.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Knock it off, Pollyanna, just 'cause you're in love doesn't mean everyone else has to be.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Love? Come on, I wouldn't call it love.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Oh no? I ain't seen you beaming like this since you broke ninety on the Blue Monster.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: An old flame?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Kind of. Ted Peloquin -- one of the sweetest guys in the world.

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: You vicious bitch, how do you sleep at night?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I can't do it -- I just found out it's his birthday.  I guess I've gotta cancel on Ted.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Holy shit...

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Puffy, get over here.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Magda!

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: The little shit lied to me about that guy!

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Oh, hi hon. Just straightening up.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Where's Puffy?

turns.speaker: MAGDA
turns.text: Ah, he was being a pest so I put him in the bathroom.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Pat's an architect, too.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Hey, no kidding? Where are your offices?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Pat does projects all over the world.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Where would I have seen your work?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: What's up, Doc?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Tucker, you look different some how. Did you do something with your hair?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: You don't think they're too big?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No no, the bigger the better.  But I must say, they could be a little brighter. Nothing's sexier than a mouthful of pearly whites.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He's a nice guy, isn't he?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Well that's what I'm trying to figure out. How long have you known him?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Not long at all, but I really like him.  Okay, I know he's a little different, Tucker, but that's what I like about him. He's a guy. A real guy. He dresses like a dork and eats corndogs and he isn't always politically correct and he probably farts, too. And that's okay with me.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: That's what you've been looking for -- a farter?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I've been looking for a guy -- not one of these South Beach pussies.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Look, it's just that something about him struck me as odd last night. He gave me this funny vibe. Anyway, I called some friends back east. They don't know of any architect named Patrick Healy and he's not listed as a Harvard alumnus.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: I thought so. Anyway, I hope you don't think I'm being meddlesome. I just think you should be careful with this guy.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No no no, Tucker, thank you.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: I mean let's face it, Mary, you're beautiful, you've got money, you trust people -- I'm just saying, there's a lot of psychos out there.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I appreciate you looking out for me.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Can I pour you one?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Thanks, but I've got to be going. Unfortunately, Doc, this isn't a social visit.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What's up?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Well... I've got a little more news about your friend Healy.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: I think you'd better sit down.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Tucker, I appreciate you doing all this, but I'm really strapped for time here and --

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Mary, the man's a killer.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What...?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: I've got a friend in the Boston police department. He faxed me this this morning. I'll just give you the highlights.  After a short stint as a petty thief, Patrick R. Healy graduated to armed robbery by the age of fourteen. At sixteen he committed his first murder -- a pretty teacher's aid named Molly Pettygrove. He was incarcerated until age twenty-two when, despite a grim psychological profile, the state was forced to release him. In his mid- twenties and again in his early thirties he was suspected of homicides in the states of Utah and Washington. Unfortunately, the bodies were so badly decomposed that there wasn't enough evidence to hold him, and on and on and so forth and so on.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I can't believe this is happening. I'm supposed to be meeting him in an hour.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Okay, just calm down. It's going to be okay.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Magda's right, I'm so lucky to have you in my life.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Don't get all gooey on me now, you'll give me a big head.  The important thing, Doctor, is you've got to distance yourself as much as possible without pissing this psycho off.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yeah, yeah. Okay, I think I know what to do. I'll call him right now.

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Uh, well... not exactly. You see, I exaggerated a little there.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You mean he's not a criminal?

turns.speaker: TUCKER
turns.text: Name's Norm. I live up in Pompano with my folks.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh Jesus...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh yeah. Fine.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thanks a lot, Ted.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Hey, you're limping. Did you just hurt yourself?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No, it's an old football injury.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, are you on the team?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No, a couple of the players and me were joking around and, uh, I fell off the school.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh he can hold you. He weighs two- hundred-and-thirty pounds.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: A real Clydesdale, huh Warren?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: So who you taking to the prom?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: The prom -- you going?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh, I don't know. I think proms are pretty dumb.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: 'Cause I thought maybe you and I could go if you weren't already taking someone.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I mean dumb in the sense that they only happen once a year.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Hi, Ted.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Hi, Mary.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm sorry. I should've told you, he's got a thing about his ears.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh. Okay. I gotcha.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Are you all right?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh yeah.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Ted, are you okay?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Just a minute.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Ted, I'm so sorry. Are you going to be okay?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You betcha!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You asshole, what are you --  Mary! Is that you?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Who's that?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh my God... Ted.  What are you...? I can't believe this. I haven't seen you since --

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yup, that's right. Junior prom... kinda.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: And did everything -- ?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh yeah, healed right up. No visible scars.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I can't believe he remembered you. He never remembers anybody.  You know I tried to call you for weeks after that.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Really? I never got a message.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That's weird. I talked to your brother Jimmy five or six times.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: By the way, how's he doing?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: He's dead.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, Ted I'm so sorry to hear that.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No, it was a good thing.  I mean, good in that it was very quick.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh. So... what brings you down here?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Funny story. You see, me and a buddy of mine decided to... ah... you know... just... drive down.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Well you look great. Are you married, do you have kids?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Nope, nope -- dodged a few bullets.  God, I cannot believe I'm standing here with Mary Jenson.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Actually, it's Mary Brooks now.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh... are you... ?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Nope, haven't walked the plank yet.  There was this guy back in college who was bothering me... got kind of ugly -- a restraining order, the whole bit. Anyway, when I got out of Princeton I changed my name as a precaution.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Jeez... that sounds awful. Hey, what do you say we go out to dinner tonight, catch up on old times?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm kidding. I'd really love to, Ted, but the thing is I already have plans. How about tomorrow night?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Mary, we haven't seen each other in twelve years.  Don't make me wait another day.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Hey.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Hi, Ted.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You look great.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Hm?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: On your ear, you've got something.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh great, I ran out.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Now by killer, you mean...?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I mean he murdered someone and did time back in Boston. The guy's a freak.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Jeez, Mary... I'm...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Well, lucky for me I found out. Thank God I have friends like Tucker.  Look, I'm sick of talking about stalkers.  Let's talk about you.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You hit the ball pretty good for a fourteen.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No short game.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We should play some time... I mean, if you can afford to lose some money.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What are you?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Twenty-two.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Bullshit, a twenty-two doesn't carry a one-iron -- don't sandbag me, lady.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Okay, sometimes I'm a nineteen.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's more like it.  Two more nitrate-sicles please.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Nitrate-sicles -- I like that.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I say they should put more meats on a stick, you know? They got a lot of sweets on sticks -- popsicles, fudgesicles, lollipops -- but hardly any meat.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I agree there should be more.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You know what I'd like to see? Meat in a cone. You could put corned beef hash in a cone, or chopped liver.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I like it. And think of the toppings -- cheese, mushrooms, mint jelly

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Not to mention ketchup and hot peppers.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's too bad you don't live down here, Ted.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We've got a lot in common.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well... why don't you move back?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Ah, my roots here are too deep. I love my practice, the people I work with, Warren's got a nice thing going  Why don't you just move down here and marry me?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: So you're a writer?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Trying to be.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Well good for you. I bet it works out for you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: We'll see. If it doesn't, what the hell, at least I gave it a shot.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That's right. And the good thing is you can do it anywhere.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What about you, Mare? How the hell'd you manage to stay single?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I don't know... My friends think I'm too picky. I think I'm just a weirdo magnet. I did come close once -- just last year, in fact. There was this guy he lived in San Francisco.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: ...and then it was all over.  We haven't spoken since.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Wow. That's too bad. He sounds almost perfect.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yeah... almost.  You want to come up and watch Sportscenter?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh no. I think I'm gonna get out while I'm ahead.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Ted... you're not that far ahead.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Look, Mary, the truth is... I'll be in town for a while now but I don't think we should see each other for a few weeks.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well... to be honest... I'm really crazy about you and it's making me nervous and when I get nervous I'm not myself and I'm afraid I'm going to doing something really dumb before we get started so I think I should just lay back until I regain my composure.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That's really sweet, Ted, but you should save it for one of your books.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: All right, let's go.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Um, Ted, I need a moment with Magda -- would you let the dog out of the bathroom.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah, sure.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh, Mare, what kind of dog is Puffy?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Toy poodle!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Get out.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Wait, hold on, Mary -- it's not as bad as it sounds. I certainly didn't know --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That you put a murderer on my trail?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well yeah, I didn't know much about him. I just thought --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What did you think, Ted? That you could spy on me and trick me into thinking you were someone I could... really go for?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Mary, I swear I wasn't trying to trick you.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Then what the fuck did you do it for?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I did it because because I'd never stopped thinking about you and if I didn't find you I knew my life would never be good again.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Please leave.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Mary, come on...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Go!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Woogie and I went out for awhile in high school.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You're Woogie?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You forgot your keys!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Ted...?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I... I just want you to be happy, Mary.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But I think I'd be happiest... with you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: But but what about Steve?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh yeah, that'd make golf real fun -- the guy doesn't even drink beer or gamble.
